evaluations: Consider Hb electrophoresis if no previous test
Investigate ESR, LFT, B12, Folate, TFT, Renal function
Examine blood film and reticulocyte count
Consider myeloma screen if malignancy is suspected

referral.haematologist: Refer if anaemia is severe, unexplained, or progressive

evaluations: Determine ferritin levels (low = primary, normal = secondary)
Consider dehydration, smoking, obesity, or cardiopulmonary issues

referral.haematologist: Refer if abnormalities persist or thrombotic events occur

evaluations: Review history for drug exposure, travel, or atopy
Repeat FBC and blood film within 1-2 weeks

referral.haematologist: Refer if eosinophils exceed 1.5 x10^9/L and persist >3 months or rise without an obvious cause

Lymphopenia.referral: Refer if lymphopenia is persistent or unexplained (consider drugs, infection, malignancy, etc.)

Lymphocytosis.referral: Refer urgently if count > 20 x10^9/L or if accompanied by lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, anaemia, weight loss, or night sweats

referral.urgent: Refer urgently if severe in unwell or febrile patients
referral.monitor: Repeat FBC in 1 week for mild neutropenia

Neutrophilia.referral: Refer if count > 15 x10^9/L or if there is splenomegaly or persistent unexplained neutrophilia

Thrombocytopenia.evaluation: Repeat FBC and review blood film to rule out artefact

referral.urgent: Urgent same-day referral if < 20 x10^9/L or with bleeding
referral.monitor: Monitor monthly if 50-100 x10^9/L and refer if progressive or symptomatic

Thrombocytosis.evaluation: If asymptomatic, repeat FBC in 4-6 weeks

referral.urgent: Urgently refer if platelets > 600 x10^9/L with symptoms or > 1000 x10^9/L
referral.haematology: Refer to haematology if thrombocytosis is persistent and unexplained
